description: Inequalities are more than abstract concepts and exercises. They help solve real life problems. Here's an example.

title: Primary documents in US government and civics
One-step inequalities review
description: Review evaluating one-step inequalities, and try some practice problems.

title: One-step addition & subtraction equations
description: Solve equations by adding and subtracting numbers from both sides.

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Learn how to solve more complex (mathematical) inequalities. Also learn to construct inequalities to model real-world situations.

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Two-step inequalities are slightly more complicated than one-step inequalities (duh!). This is a worked example of solving ⅔>-4y-8⅓.

title: Area and circumference of circles
description: A circle is at the foundation of geometry, and at the foundation of a circle is a special number called Pi. This number allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Two-step inequalities
description: Solve inequalities that take two steps to solve. For example, solve 3x + 2 > 5.

title: Radius, diameter, circumference & π
description: Learn how the number Pi allows us to relate the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: Two-step inequality word problem: apples
description: We'll talk you through this fun and challenging inequality problem.

title: Labeling parts of a circle
description: Radius, diameter, center, and circumference--all are parts of a circle. Let's go through each and understand how they are defined.

title: Two-step inequality word problem: R&B
description: Let's tackle this word problem together. We'll interpret the information and then construct a linear inequality to solve it.

title: Radius, diameter, & circumference
description: Learn the relationship between the radius, diameter, and circumference of a circle.

title: One-step multiplication and division equations
description: Solve equations by multiplying and dividing numbers from both sides.

title: Two-step inequality word problems
description: Practice constructing, interpreting, and solving linear inequalities that model real-world situations.

title: Radius & diameter from circumference
description: Sal finds the radius and diameter of a circle given the circumference.

title: Fourier coefficients for sine terms
description: Fourier coefficients for sine terms

title: Circumference of a circle
description: Find the circumference of a circle when given either the radius or diameter.  Find the radius or diameter of a circle when given the circumference.

title: Electric force and electric field
description: The force between electric charges is described by Coulomb's Law. We develop the concept of an *electric field* filling the space surrounding charges.

title: Area of a circle
description: The area of a circle is pi times the radius squared (A = π r²). Learn how to use this formula to find the area of a circle when given the diameter.

title: Electric force
description: Electric force exists between charges, as described by Coulomb's Law. Worked example: a line of charge with q off the end. Written by Willy McAllister.

title: Finding mistakes in one-step equations
description: Practice spotting the mistake in someone else's work as they attempt to solve one-step equations.

title: Area of a circle
description: Find the area of a circle given its radius, diameter, or circumference.

title: Inverse square law
description: The fable of the butter gun. Intuitive explanation of the inverse square law. Written by Willy McAllister.

title: Partial circle area and arc length
description: Sal finds the area of a semicircle and the arc length of a partial circle.

title: Electric field
description: Definition of the electric field. Electric field near a point charge. Written by Willy McAllister.

title: Circumference of parts of circles
description: Practice finding the  circumference of part of a circle.

title: One-step equation word problems
description: Let's use our algebra tools to solve a problem of earth-shattering importance: which Super Yoga plan is the best value! In this word problem, you'll put to practice your knowledge of variables, substitution, and one-step equations.

title: Fields, potential, and voltage
description: Worked examples of the electric field near a line of charge, and near a plane of charge. Formal definitions of *electric potential* and *voltage*.

title: Area of parts of circles
description: Practice finding the area of part of a circle.

title: Line of charge
description: Advanced example: Electric field surrounding a uniformly charged infinite line. Written by Willy McAllister.

title: Circumference review
description: Review the basics of circumference and try some practice problems.

title: Plane of charge
description: Advanced example: Electric field generated by a uniformly-charged infinite plane. Written by Willy McAllister.

title: Area of circles review
description: Review the basics of area of circles and try some practice problems.

title: Intro to inequalities with variables
description: Algebraic inequalities (inequalities with variables) are useful for describing real-world situations. Learn how to write inequalities and graph them on the number line.

title: Area and circumference challenge problems
description: Problems that stretch your understanding of area and circumference of circles

title: Finding circumference of a circle when given the area
description: Learn how to find the circumference, the distance around a circle, when given the area.

title: Electric potential, voltage
description: Formal definition of electric potential and voltage. Written by Willy McAllister.

title: Area of a shaded region
description: Here's a fun one: find the area of a shaded region where you first determine the area of a square and then the area of a circle.

title: Impact of increasing the radius
description: If we change the radius of a circle, how does the circumference and area change?

title: Area of composite figures
description: Finding the area of more complex shapes like trapezoids and composite figures (shapes built from other shapes)

title: Circumference and rotations
description: Determine distance or number of rotations when given circumference, radius, or diameter of a circle.

title: Area and circumference of circles challenge
description: Practice interesting area and circumference problems.

title: Fourier series
description: The Fourier Series is a way to approximate any arbitrary periodic signal as the sum of sines and cosines.

title: Fourier Series introduction
description: The Fourier Series allows us to model any arbitrary periodic signal with a combination of sines and cosines. In this video sequence Sal works out the Fourier Series of a square wave.

title: Shaded areas
description: Find the areas of shaded regions which are combinations of squares, triangles, and circles.

title: Vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles
description: Learn three types of angle pairs: vertical angles, complementary angles, and supplementary angles.

title: Integral of sin(mt) and cos(mt)
description: Integrating sin(mt) and cos(mt) over a full period equals zero.

title: Geometric solids (3D shapes)
description: Identify 3-dimensional figures and their parts (faces, edges, vertices).

title: Integral of sine times cosine
description: Definite integral of the product of sine and cosine. Integrating sin(mt) * cos(nt) over a full period equals zero for any integer m and n.

title: Dependent and independent variables
description: Sometimes one variable depends on another. For example, the amount of money you make might depend on how many hours you work.

title: Complementary & supplementary angles
description: Learn about complementary and supplementary angles, as well as the definitions of adjacent and straight angles.

title: Integral of product of sines
description: Definite integral of product of sines. The integral of sin(mt) * sin(nt) = 0, except for the special case when m = n. When m = n, the integral evaluates to pi.

title: Identifying supplementary, complementary, and vertical angles
description: Practice telling whether two angles are supplementary, complementary, or vertical.

title: Integral of product of cosines
description: Definite integral of the product of cosines. The integral of cos(mt) * cos(nt) = 0, except for the special case when m = n. When m = n, the integral evaluates to pi.

title: Volume with fractions
description: Finding the volume of rectangular prisms that have fractional side lengths

title: Complementary and supplementary angles (visual)
description: Use your knowledge about complementary and supplementary angles to find missing angles.

title: First term in a Fourier series
description: The first term in a Fourier series is the average value (DC value) of the function being approximated.

title: Complementary and supplementary angles (no visual)
description: Use complementary and supplementary angles to solve for a missing angle measure.

title: Fourier coefficients for cosine terms
description: Fourier coefficients for cosine terms

title: Complementary and supplementary angles review
description: Review the basics of complementary and supplementary angles, and try some practice problems.

title: Finding Fourier coefficients for square wave
description: Finding Fourier coefficients for a square wave

title: Vertical angles
description: By using our knowledge of supplementary, adjacent, and vertical angles, we can solve problems involving the intersection of two lines. Including this one!

title: Vertical angles
description: Use your knowledge about vertical angles to find missing angle measures.

title: Visualizing the Fourier expansion of a square wave
description: Visualize the Fourier expansion of a square wave. A square wave can be approximated by adding odd harmonics of a sine wave.

title: Finding angle measures between intersecting lines
description: Use your knowledge about angles to find missing angle measures in various situations.

title: Basic probability
description: Flip a quarter a hundred times. What's the probability that it will turn up heads? Tails?    Even if we are unsure about whether something will happen, can we start to be mathematical about the "chances" of an event (essentially realizing that some things are more likely than others) occurring.  This tutorial will introduce us to the tools that allow us to think about random events and the logic behind comparing, judging, and finding the probabilities of those events.

title: Surface area
description: Learn how to find the total area of the surfaces of 3D shapes. To do this, we wrap 3D shapes in 2D nets.

title: All about Spout
description: This topic explains how Spout works! It was created by Karl R. C. Wendt.

title: Find measure of vertical angles
description: Given two intersecting lines and the measure of vertical angles, watch as we solve to find the measure of the remaining angles.

title: Simple probability: yellow marble
description: In order to find the probability of picking a yellow marble from a bag, we have to first determine the number of possible outcomes, and then how many of them meet our constraints.

title: Finding missing angles
description: Practice using knowledge of vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles to find a missing angle.

title: Dot plots & frequency tables
description: A dot plot is like a bar chart, but it displays data using dots (not bars). And a frequency table is like a dot plot, but it displays data in a simple table (not a fancy diagram).

title: Find measure of angles word problem
description: Solve this word problem to find the measure of angles. In this example you'll split up a pie (don't forget to share!)

title: Simple probability: non-blue marble
description: In this example we are figuring out the probability of randomly picking a non-blue marble from a bag. Again, we'll have to think about the possible outcomes first.

title: Equation practice with complementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of complementary angles, learn how to form and solve an equation to find an unknown angle.

title: Simple probability
description: Practice finding probabilities of events, such as rolling dice, drawing marbles out of a bag, and spinning spinners.

title: Equation practice with supplementary angles
description: Given the algebraic expressions that represent a pair of supplementary angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Equation practice with vertical angles
description: Given algebraic expressions that represent a pair of vertical angles, Sal forms and solves an equation.

title: Experimental probability
description: Practice making reasonable estimates of the likelihood of future events based on past experience.

title: Create equations to solve for missing angles
description: Use understanding of vertical, complementary, and supplementary angles to set up an appropriate equation to solve for a missing angle measure.

title: Intuitive sense of probabilities
description: Think about what probabilities really mean. What does a probability of 0 mean? How about 1?

title: Unknown angle problems (with algebra)
description: Practice setting up algebraic equations to solve unknown angle problems.

title: Comparing probabilities
description: Practice expressing probabilities in different forms (fractions, decimals, and percents).

title: Ant bot
description: Build an ant colony with simple behaviours

title: Statistical questions
description: Statistics help us answer many questions, but not all questions are statistical. In this tutorial, we'll learn to tell the difference between a statistical question and a non-statistical question.

title: Constructing triangles
description: Let's practice making triangles and start thinking about when it's possible or impossible to make a triangle.

title: Probability models
description: In many situations, we don't know exact probabilities, so we estimate probability based on history of events.

title: Construct a right isosceles triangle
description: Can you build a triangle that is both a right triangle and an isosceles triangle?

title: Polygons on the coordinate plane
description: Math problems that test your understanding of polygons and points on the coordinate plane

title: Theoretical and experimental probabilities
description: Compare expected probabilities to what really happens when we run experiments.

title: Histograms
description: Histograms are similar to dot plots and bar graphs, but they work a little bit differently. In this tutorial, we'll learn how histograms work and when to use them.

title: Construct a triangle with constraints
description: Here's a challenge: in this problem we are given constraints and asked to construct a triangle. It can be done! You'll learn about degenerate triangles, too.

title: Making predictions with probability
description: Predict the number of times a spinner will land on an elephant.

title: Triangle inequality theorem
description: Intuition behind the triangle inequality theorem

title: Making predictions with probability
description: Practice predicting the number of times a certain event will happen.

title: Triangle side length rules
description: Given the lengths of two sides of a triangle, what can we say about the third side?

title: Probability models example: frozen yogurt
description: Model the probability of a frozen yogurt line having 0, 1, or 2 people in it.

title: Light guitar
description: Get to know your light sensor while building musical instruments

title: Spider Bot
description: Spider Bot is a low cost robot made of recycled components and designed by Karl R. C. Wendt

title: Neolithic Revolution and the birth of agriculture
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on the Neolithic Revolution!

title: Slicing geometric shapes
description: When we slice (cut through) a 3D shape, we make a 2D shape called a cross section. In this tutorial, we think about the different cross sections we can make by slicing 3D shapes.

title: Probability models
description: Practice creating probability models and understand what makes a valid probability model.

title: Mean and median
description: Mean and median are measures of "central tendency." That is, they help us find the center (or middle) of the data. In this tutorial, we'll learn how to compute mean and median.

title: Slicing a rectangular pyramid
description: What happens when you slice vertically into a rectangular pyramid? What kind of geometric shape results?

title: Compound events and sample spaces
description: Learn about sample spaces and probability for compound events.  Learn the counting principle.

title: Cross sections of 3D objects (basic)
description: Match 3D objects with their 2D cross-sections.

title: Sample spaces for compound events
description: Explore the notion of a "sample space". See a sample space represented as a tree diagram, table, and list.

title: Sample spaces for compound events
description: Practice checking if sample space diagrams match a compound event.

title: Exploring scale copies
description: Sal uses virtual manipulatives to identify figures that scale proportionally.

title: Die rolling probability
description: We're thinking about the probability of rolling doubles on a pair of dice. Let's create a grid of all possible outcomes.

title: Explore scale copies
description: Visually identify scaled copies of a figure.

title: Probability of a compound event
description: Learn how to use sample space diagrams to find probabilities.

title: Identifying corresponding parts of scaled copies
Probabilities of compound events
description: Practice using sample space diagrams to find probabilities.

title: The origin of humans and early human societies
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on prehistory!

title: Byzantine Empire
description: An overview of the history of the Byzantine Empire. Continuity and change after the fall of Rome.

title: Corresponding points and sides of scaled shapes
description: Sal identifies corresponding sides and corresponding points in scale copies of figures.

title: Mean and median challenge problems
description: Practice solving more challenging problems using your knowledge of mean and median.

title: Counting outcomes: flower pots
description: Find the number of ways you can put four types of flowers into three types of pots.

title: Corresponding sides and points
description: Identify corresponding sides and points in scale copies of figures.

title: Count outcomes using tree diagram
description: Tree diagrams display all the possible outcomes of an event. Each branch in a tree diagram represents a possible outcome. Tree diagrams can be used to find the number of possible outcomes and calculate the probability of possible outcomes.

title: Identifying scale copies
description: Sal looks at side measures on figures to determine if they are scale copies.

title: The counting principle
description: Practice counting possible outcomes in a variety of situations. These problems cover everything from counting the number of ways to get dressed in the morning to counting the number of ways to build a custom pizza.

title: Identify scale copies
description: Determine if one polygon is a scale copy of another.

title: Digital camera
description: Digital Camera

title: 3rd graders build robots at Santa Rita Elementary School
description:
Mrs. Rowhani's third graders learn about matter and energy by building a Spout bot with Khan Academy. 

Special thanks to: Santa Rita's volunteer parents, Kami Thordarson, Karen Wilson and of course Laleh Rowhani the class teacher.

title: Comparing and sampling populations
description: When we are trying to make a judgement about a population, it is often impractical (or impossible) to observe every member of the population.  Imagine trying to survey all 300+ million Americans to understand the likely outcome of the next presidential election!  Because of this, much of statistics is collecting data from a representative and random sample.  From the data collected from this random sample we can infer things about the greater population.

title: Identifying scale factor in drawings
description: Identify the scale factor used to create a scale copy.

title: Reasonable samples
description: To make a valid conclusion, you'll need a representaive, not skewed, sample.

title: Valid claims
description: Practice figuring out whether we took a random sample and whether we're able to draw valid conclusions from our data.

title: Identify scale factor in scale drawings
description: Identify scale factor in scale copies of figures.

title: Interpreting scale factors in drawings
description: Sal interprets a scale factor to determine if a scale copy will be larger or smaller than the original figure.

title: Interquartile range (IQR)
description: Interquartile range (IQR) is a tool for reasoning about the spread of data. Higher values of IQR tell you the data is more spread out. Lower values of IQR tell you the data is closer together.

title: Making inferences from random samples
description: Given a random sample, practice figuring out what can we reasonably infer about the entire population?

title: Comparing distributions with dot plots (example problem)
description: Sal examines two distributions in dot plots to draw conclusions about the times of Olympic swimmers.

title: Interpret scale factor in scale drawings
Comparing distributions
description: Practice comparing distributions that are presented in dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

title: Box plots
description: Whether you're looking at scientific data or stock price charts, box-and-whisker plots can illuminate patterns in your life. This tutorial covers what they are, how to read them, and how to construct them.

title: Spout's reversing circuit and final assembly
Introduction
description: Introduction to the Lego NXT environment and what it is capable of. We begin with a few mini projects.

title: Scale drawings
description: A map depicts objects much smaller than they are in real life. A map is a great example of a scale drawing. In this tutorial, we'll take a mathematical look at the nature of scale drawings.

title: Anything is possible!
description: Anything robots can do, lego robots can do!

title: Scale drawings
description: Sal finds a missing side length in a scale drawing when given either a set of corresponding side lengths or one side length and the scale factor.

title: Scale drawing: centimeters to kilometers
description: Sal uses ratios to figure out how far apart two cities should be on a map.

title: DLab: Inspired by sumo robots
description: Inspiration from Khan Academy's Discovery Lab

title: Spout Bot with Solder
description: This project is based  on a MAKE Beetle bot. The tutorial was created by Karl R.C. Wendt.

title: Scale drawings
description: Find a missing side length in a scale drawing when given either a set of corresponding side lengths or one side length and the scale factor.

title: Introduction to programming using lego NXT
description: Get to know the NXT-G environment

title: Interpreting a scale drawing
description: Understand how a scale drawing is converted into real numbers using the scale factor.

title: Scale drawing word problems
description: Use scale drawings to solve problems in real-world contexts.

title: Mean absolute deviation (MAD)
description: Mean absolute deviation (MAD) is a tool for reasoning about the spread of data, just like interquartile range (IQR). Higher values of MAD tell you the data is more spread out. Lower values of MAD tell you the data is closer together.

title: Creating scale drawings
description: Sal uses real world contexts to create scale drawings on a grid.

title: Making a scale drawing
description: An urban planner needs your help in creating a scale drawing. Let's use our knowledge about scale factor, length, and area to assist.

title: Construct scale drawings
description: An urban planner needs your help in creating a scale drawing. Let's use our knowledge about scale factor, length, and area to assist.

title: Demo: light guitar
description: Light guitar in action!

title: Comparing data displays
description: Learn how to interpret and compare dot plots, histograms, and box plots.

title: Scale factors and area
description: Sal explore how scale factor affects the area of a scaled figure.

title: Data wires
description: data wires allow you to send values directly from input sensors to output devices

title: Math block
description: Math blocks allow you to scale values (and much more!)

title: Solving a scale drawing word problem
description: See how we solve a word problem by using a scale drawing and finding the scale factor.

title: Shape of data distributions
description: Like people, no two data distributions look exactly the same. Well, maybe that's not always true... Anyway, the point is that each data distribution has it's own shape. In this tutorial, you'll learn new vocabulary that will have you discussing the shape of data distributions like a pro in no time!

title: Relate scale drawings to area
description: Understand how creating a scale copy of a figure affects the area of the figure.

title: Spout Bot without Solder
description: This project is based  on a MAKE Beetle bot. The tutorial was created by Karl R. C. Wendt.

title: Volume and surface area word problems
description: Learn to find volume of rings, triangular prisms, and rectangular prisms inside of other rectangular prisms.

title: Volume word problem: gold ring
description: See if you can find the incremental volume of a ring in cubic inches. You'll need to put to use your knowledge of how to measure volume.

title: Demo: coin detector
description: demonstration of a simple coin detector

title: Volume of triangular prism & cube
description: Using the formulas for the volume of triangular prism and cube to solve some solid geometry problems.

title: Construction
description: You can get started with this simple design, then add your own complexity after!

title: Volume of rectangles inside rectangles
description: How many crates can we fit into a boxcar? We'll explain that there's more than one way to solve for the volume in this problem.

title: Rotation sensor
description: Familiarize yourself with rotation sensor. Build a volume knob

title: Tools and parts to build a Spout
description: Make Spout a low cost beetle bot that can avoid obstacles. Spout is low cost and can be made without solder.

title: Volume and surface area word problems
description: Solve word problems involving volume and surface area involving 3D shapes, including composite figures.

title: Switch statements & logic
description: Control switch statments using logic

title: What is inside an alarm clock radio?
description: In this video we explore what is inside an alarm clock, how it is made, and how it works.

title: Design review (calibration)
description: Final step in the coin detector challenge

title: What is inside a coffee maker?
description: In this video we explore what is inside a coffee maker, how it is made, and how it works.

title: Polling sensors
description: Check the real-time values of your sensors

description: Before you begin, find out a little more about the discipline of World History!

description: The origin of humans and early human societies, a tutorial in Technological and environmental transformations (to c. 600 BCE), the first period in the AP World History course.

description: demonstration of a basic ant bot

title: What is inside a hair dryer? (2 of 2)
description: In this video we explore what is inside a hairdryer, how it is made, and how it works.

title: History and prehistory
description: How do we know what we know about prehistory, the time before the invention of writing? Sal explains.

description: In this video we compare our hair dryer motor to the motor we built.

title: Homo sapiens and early human migration
description: Homo sapiens evolved from their early hominid predecessors between 200,000 and 300,000 years ago and developed a capacity for language about 50,000 years ago.

description: In this video we explore the power supply inside a DVD player.

description: In this video we explore the control board inside a DVD player.

description: In this video we explore what is inside a universal remote control, how it is made, and how it works.

Vicki Lombardi's 6th grade students at Santa Rita Elementary in Los Altos School district learn how to build a Spider robot.

Read more at: http://lasdilearn.blogspot.com/2013/02/third-graders-building-robots-mission.html

title: The Neolithic Revolution and early agriculture
description: How, why, and when did agriculture first emerge, and what were its implications on human society? Sal explains in an overview.

title: What is inside a digital camera? (1 of 2)
description: In this video we go inside the digital camera to discover what is inside and how it works.

title: The spread of agriculture
description: We investigate the independent development and spread of agriculture across the planet, throughout prehistory.

description: In this video we show you how to connect Spider's motors and batteries

title: Ancient Persia
description: An overview of the ancient Persian empire, with focus on the Achaemenid Empire started by Cyrus the Great and ended by Alexander the Great.

title: Ancient Persia
description: This overview of Ancient Persia explains the origins of the term "Persia" and Zoroastrianism; it also puts the Median, Achaemenid, Seleucid, Parthian, Sassanian dynasties in context.

title: Ancient Mesopotamia
description: Why is Mesopotamia considered the "cradle of civilization"? Sal explains the history of the early empires on the Tigris and Euphrates rivers.

title: Justinian and the Byzantine Empire
description: Overview of the Byzantine Empire under its greatest strength under Justinian and then eventual slow decline over the next 900 years. Code of Justinian. Hagia Sophia. Empress Theodora's role in putting down the Nika Riots.

title: Zoroastrianism
description: A primer on the Zoroastrian religion. Discussions of Zarathustra, Ahura Mazda and the Avesta.

title: Ancient Mesopotamia and the Hebrew Bible
description: High level overview from Ancient Egypt to Babylon with reference to stories from the Old Testament

title: Comparing Roman and Byzantine Empires
description: Similarities and differences between the Roman Empire and the "Byzantine Empire" (which considered itself the continuation of the Roman Empire).

title: Cyrus the Great and the Achaemenid Empire
description: Cyrus the Great overthrows the Medians to establish the Achaemenid Empire (Persian Empire).

title: Byzantine culture and society
description: Learn more about Byzantine culture and society.

title: Lesson summary: Ancient Mesopotamia
description: An overview of ancient Mesopotamia.

title: Focus on continuity and change: Byzantine state-building
description: Read a passage and answer questions about changes and continuities in the Byzantine state.

title: Ancient Mesopotamia
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on ancient Mesopotamia!

title: Ancient Persia
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on ancient Persia

title: European Middle Ages: feudalism and serfdom
description: An overview of the history of European serfdom in the Medieval period

title: Ancient Egypt
description: When we think of the ancient world, the Egyptian pyramids and hieroglyphics come to mind, and for good reason. Ancient Egypt is one of the first and longest last significant civilizations that we currently know of. We will also discuss one of their key rivals, the Hittites.

title: Overview of the Middle Ages
description: The European Middle Ages (or Medieval Time) is roughly 1000 year span of time from the end of the Roman Empire (in the West) to the beginning of the Renaissance. This video gives as overview with maps and touches on the key events like the Great Schism, Crusades and Black Death.

title: Classical Greece
description: Greece fights off the Persians and enters its Golden Era, only to breakdown into the Peloponnesian war and eventual conquest by the Macedonians.

title: Ancient Egypt and the Nile River Valley
description: Ancient Egypt was an early example of a massive civilization spanning thousands of years. Sal explains this history in an overview.

title: Classical Greece
description: Sal provides an overview of ancient Greece from the Greek Dark Ages to Archaic Greece to the Classical and Hellenistic periods. Familiarity with the major greek city-states (especially Athens and Sparta), including the most known traditions.

title: Feudal system during the Middle Ages
description: An overview of the Feudal System--the relationship of lords and vassals. Titles of nobility such as dukes, earls, counts, viscounts and barons. Homage and fealty.

title: Serfs and manorialism
description: An overview of how a manor was organized in Medieval Europe. Discussion of serfs and serfdom.

title: Classical Greek Society and Culture
description: Overview of cultural contributions of Classical Greece. Golden Age of Athens. Age of Pericles.

title: Spider's romance
description: Happy Valentines Day from Khan Academy Projects

title: Topic A: Lessons 1-3: Arithmetic sequence formulas
Topic B: Lesson 14: Graphing factored polynomials
Topic A: Lessons 7-8: Complex number division
Topic B: Lessons 10-11: Simplifying rational expressions
Measuring angles
description: Learn how to measure angles using a protractor.

title: Angles with polygons
description: Explore properties of angles in and arou polygons.

title: The Hittite Empire and the Battle of Kadesh
description: Who were the Hittites, and why was iron so important to them? Sal covers the history of the Hittite Empire, a civilization in Asia Minor that was among the first peoples to master ironworking. Iron tools, weapons, and chariots gave the Hittites a decisive advantage in combat, and it enabled them to conquer and hold territory.

title: Serfdom in Europe
description: As the Western Roman Empire collapsed, landholders gradually transitioned from outright slavery to serfdom, a system in which unfree laborers were tied to the land.

title: Focus on economics: serfdom
description: Let's dive into some passages about serfdom in post-Carolingian Europe.

title: Ben Eater's Spider
description: In this video Karl talks to Ben Eater about his improvements to the Spider bot platform.

title: Peasant revolts
description: Learn about popular uprisings in late medieval Europe. Why did people rebel against authority and did they achieve anything in doing so? Were these really peasant revolts?

title: Lesson summary: Ancient Egypt
description: An overview of ancient Egypt.

title: Philosophy: Socrates, Plato and Aristotle
description: Introduction to the Greek philosophers Socrates, Plato and Aristotle.

title: An overview of the Crusades (part 2)
description: An overview of the 2nd through 9th Crusades. Saladin retakes Jerusalem after nearly 90 years as a Crusader Kingdom in 1179. The sacking of Constantinople and the possible Children's Crusade. The Reconquista in what will eventually be Spain.

title: Bit-zee Bot
description: This project is a low cost robot made from every day items that are taken apart and described in the reverse engineering section. This project was created by Karl R. C. Wendt.

title: Greco Persian Wars
description: What were the Greco Persian wars and how did they start? Sal explains.

title: Ancient Egypt
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on ancient Egypt!

title: Bit-zeeeeeeeeeee
description: Bit-zee is a project designed to inspire students to explore math and science. It was created from everyday items (a hair dryer, tap light, alarm clock, digital camera, and a universal remote). See the following link for help with the code https://sites.google.com/site/khanacademyprojects/home

title: Focus on rebellion: Peasant revolts
description: Read passages and answer questions about peasant revolts.

title: Second Persian Invasion
description: Xerxes launches an attack on Greece by land and by sea, culminating in the Battle of Thermopylae.

title: Ancient India
description: Over 4000 years ago, the Indus Valley Civilization (Harappan) was one of the few technologically sophisticated civilizations on the plant. Their society declined for unknown reasons, but it roughly coincides with the migration of Indo-Aryans from the north west which starts the Vedic Period.

title: Bit-zeeeeeeeeeee (long version)
description: Bit-zee goes to school

title: Origins of Islam
description: An overview of the origins of Islam, including the life of Muhammad, the Hijra to Medina, and the conversion of Mecca.

title: Indus River Valley civilizations
description: The Indus River Valley (or Harappan) civilization lasted for 2,000 years, and extended from what is today northeast Afghanistan to Pakistan and northwest India.  Sal explores the history of this civilization, its technological innovations, its art, its architectural practices, and its agriculture.

title: The Peloponnesian War
description: An overview of the Peloponnesian War, including the Archidamian War, the Athenian attack on Syracuse, and the Decelean War.

title: The Standard of Ur
description: Standard of Ur, c. 2600-2400 B.C.E., 21.59 x 49.5 x 12 cm (British Museum) Speakers: Dr. Steven Zucker & Dr. Beth Harris

title: Motor controller connections
description: In this video we show you how to attach and wire the L-298 motor controller board to Bit-zee's frame.

title: Golden Age of Islam
description: An overview of the Golden Age of Islam and the discoveries and re-discoveries of knowledge in Baghdad during this time.

title: Arduino connections
description: In this video we show you how to connect Bit-zee's Arduino micro-controller to his frame.

title: The Crusades
description: What were the Crusades? Why did people go on them? What were the long-term impacts?

title: Medieval Japan
description: In the post-classical period, Japan was united by common language, culture, and economic structures, but government was decentralized.

title: Introduction to Islam
description: A high level overview of Islam, the 5 pillars of Sunni Islam, and the Muslim belief that Islam is the extension of the faith of Abraham, Moses and Jesus.

title: Lesson summary: Classical Greece
description: An overview of ancient Greek city-states and politics.

title: Beginnings of Islam: The life of Muhammad
description: The early life of Muhammad including his work as a merchant, his marriage to Khadijah, his early revelations and the persecution of early Muslims by his own Quraysh tribe.

title: Classical Greece
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on ancient Greek history!

title: The Vedic Period
description: From the Vedas, the oldest known Hindu scriptures, scholars have learned about the existence of the Vedic period in ancient Indian history that followed the Indus River Valley civilization. Sal explains more about this early society.

title: Introduction
description: In this video we discuss some of the key parts of Bit-zee

title: Beginnings of Islam: The Hijra to Medina and the conversion of Mecca
description: Early Muslims escape Quraysh persecution by migrating to Medina in 622. With Medina as the base of their community, they are able to convert Mecca and most of Arabia to Islam during the remainder of the life of Muhammed (next 10 years).

title: The rise and fall of empires
description: A survey of the Macedonian conquests of Greece and Persia that lead to the rise of Hellenism

title: Sanskrit connections to English
description: How Sanskrit is connected to Latin, English and other European languages.

title: Contextualization of the development of Islam
description: Why did Islam emerge and spread when and where it did? Why was it so rapid?

title: Planning and propulsion
description: The video covers the first stages of idea generation for Bit-zee and how to make Bit-zee move.

title: Alexander the Great takes power
description: Alexander the Great takes power.

title: Lesson summary: Indus River Valley
description: An overview of Indus River Valley civilizations.

title: Focus on context: The origins of Islam
description: Let's dive into some scholarly texts about this early period of Islam

title: Parts
description: In this video we take a quick a look at some of the parts we used to make Bit-zee. Although we highly recommend you create your own Bit-zee using parts from products that people would otherwise throw away.

title: Ancient India
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on the Indus River Valley.

title: Chassis/frame
description: In this video we show you how to craft the chassis for the Bit-zee using a \$3 piece of Lexan and tap light housing

title: Spread of Islam
description: As people traveled and traded across the world, Islam spread to those new places.

title: Shang China
description: The Shang Dynasty is the earliest dynasty for which there is a strong historical record in China. The Xia Dynasty purportedly predates it, but historians debate its historicity.

title: Alexander the Great conquers Persia
description: How did Alexander the Great take over Persia? Sal explains.

title: The spread of Islam
description: Overview of the spread of Islam from the time of Muhammed to the Rashidun, Umayyad and Abbasid Caliphates. Discussion of Muslim conquest and conversion.

title: Wheel mounts and fenders
description: In this video we show you how to create Bit-zee's fenders out of hair dryer motor mounts and we also take you through how to mount the hair dryer motors in Bit-zee's frame.

title: Shang Dynasty in Ancient China
description: At the end of the Mythic Period of China's history, the Xia dynasty gave way to the Shang Dynasty… if the Xia really existed at all!  Sal gives an overview of the Xia, Shang, and Zhou Dynasties—societies that lived between the Yellow and Yangtze Rivers—and discusses their cultural practices, their bronzeworking, and the origins of a Chinese identity.

title: Comparison: Rise of empires
description: Comparing what led to the rise of Achaemenid Persia, Maurya India, Han China, and the Roman Empire.

title: Component mounting holes
description: In this video we show you how and where to create the mounting holes in BIt-zee's Lexan base for the arduino, batteries, camera, on/off switch and wire routing.

title: The rise of Islamic empires and states
description: Learn about the Arab Muslim conquests and the establishment of the caliphate.

title: Diadochi and the Hellenistic Period
description: Alexander's Empire fragments into Seleucid Persia, Ptolemaic Egypt and Antigonid Macedonia (and other kingdoms) and gives rise to the Hellenistic Period.

title: Batteries/power
description: In this video we install 8 AA batteries in Bit-zee's frame using zip ties.

title: Spread of Islamic Culture
description: Learn more about the spread of Islamic culture.

title: Lesson summary: Shang China
description: An overview of Shang China.

title: Battery wires
description: In this video we upgrade Bit-zee' battery wires from 32 gage to 18 gauge.

title: The development and spread of Islamic cultures
Shang China practice
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on Shang China!

title: Comparison: Fall of empires
description: Sal and World History Fellow Steven Schroeder discuss the fall of empires, from Achaemenid Persia, the Maurya Empire in India, the Han Empire in China, and the Roman Kingdom, Republic, and Empire in the Mediterranean.

title: Ancient art and artifacts
description: Art history videos and other content from prehistory to 600 BCE that could supplement AP instruction.

title: Power wires and on/off switch
description: In this video we show you how to switch on and off Bit-zee's electrical power.

title: Focus on continuity and change: the spread of Islam
description: Read passages and answer questions about patterns of continuity and change during the rise of Islamic empires and states.

title: Comparing the rise and fall of empires
Motors/propulsion
description: In this video we re-wire Bit-zee's motors to include longer wires and then we re-attach them to his frame. This video shows more detail than the previous motor video and it is shot in real time. This video also shows how to route the wires.

title: Sunni and Shia Islam
description: A high-level overview of two major types of Islam: Sunni and Shia.

title: Lesson summary: the rise and fall of empires
The Rosetta Stone
description: Rosetta Stone, 196 B.C.E., granite, 114.4 cm x 72.3 x 27.9 cm or 45 x 28.5 x 11 inches, Ptolemaic Period (British Museum, London). Speakers: Dr. Beth Harris and Dr. Steven Zucker

title: Motor controller functions
description: This video outlines in simple terms why a motor controller is needed and what it does

title: Sunni and Shia Islam part 1
description: An introduction to the Sunni and Shia schism that forms in Islam after the death of Muhammed.

title: Human innovation and the environment
description:
Where do we think humans come from?  How and why have we developed as a species.  This tutorial attempts to give an overview of these truly fundamental questions.

From human evolution (which is covered in more depth in the biology playlist) to the development of agriculture, this tutorial will give you an appreciation of where we've been (and maybe where we're going).

title: Focus on state-building: Empires
description: Read passages and test your knowledge of early empires!

title: Motor controller
description: In this video we take you step by step through building the L298 Motor driver. This controller allows you to use your Arduino to control the hair dryer motors used to move the Bit-zee bot.

title: Sunni and Shia Islam part 2
description: As Ali becomes caliph, the Ummayads under the leadership of Muawiya refuse to recognize him, sparking the first Muslim Civil War. The increased division leads eventually to the Tragedy at Karbala which is a defining event for Shia Muslims.

title: Ancient Rome
description: Starting as a small kingdom city-state on the Italian peninsula before the 8th century BCE, Rome grows first into a republic that dominates the Mediterranean and Europe and lays the foundation for Western Civilization.

title: An Overview of Ancient Rome
description: Conquering armies, monumental architecture, and beautiful art: how did Rome achieve all of this? Sal provides an overview of the origins of the Roman Empire.

title: Golden age of Islam
description: The Abbasid Caliphate becomes a center of learning from the 9th to the 13th centuries, collecting the knowledge of India, China and ancient Greece while also making significant new contributions to mathematics, astronomy, philosophy, medicine and geography.

title: Roman social and political structures
description: Patricians and plebeians; Roman citizens, Senators and Consuls: learn about the political and social structures of ancient Rome.

title: The golden age of Islam
description: The Abbasid caliphs established the city of Baghdad in 762 CE. It became a center of learning and the hub of what is known as the Golden Age of Islam.

title: Great Schism or East-West Schism part 1
description: After the fall of the Western Roman Empire in the 5th Century, division between the Latin Church in the West and the Greek-speaking church in the East widen over issues such as primacy of the Bishop of Rome, iconoclasm, filioque and the crowning of Charlemagne as Holy Roman Emperor.

title: Digital camera connections
description: This video shows you how to "hotwire" a digital camera. This video outlines the first step in making our digital camera work in the Bit-zee robot. The required voltage for the camera was determined by adding the1.5 volt AAA batteries (there are three of them) together to get 4.5 volts (because the batteries are wired in series). Since new batteries usually have a voltage that exceeds their marked rating the camera can easily run on the 5 volts that the center terminal of our L298 motor controller provides.

title: Focus on Baghdad: the golden age of Islam
description: Read passages about Baghdad and the Abbasid caliphate and answer questions.

title: Exchange between Rome, Carthage, and the Phoenicians
description: Sal teaches an introduction to the Carthaginians and their roots as a Phoenician (Punic) colony.

title: Digital camera connections II
description: In this video we show you how to attach Bit-zee's camera and route the wires

title: Rise of Julius Caesar
description: Julius Caesar conquers Gaul and ignites a civil war.

title: Intro to adding negative numbers
description: Learn how to add negative numbers. By the end of this tutorial, you'll be solving problems like 4 + (-7) with ease!

title: Christianity in the Roman Empire
description: Overview of the changing relationship between the Roman Empire and Christianity from the time of Jesus to the reign of Theodosius.

title: 5 volt power distribution board
description: In this video we hack apart a bread board to create a 5 volt power distribution strip. The 5 volts comes from the center pin in the motor controller and the negative or ground comes from the ground pin on the motor controller.

title: The Council of Nicaea
description: The attempted unification of church doctrine by Constantine through the Council of Nicaea. Especially resolving the Arian Controversy (based on the views of Arius of Alexandria). The Nicene Creed. Seeds of eventual schism in the church.

title: Caesar, Cleopatra and the Ides of March
description: Julius Caesar installs Cleopatra as Pharaoh in Ptolemaic Egypt and becomes Dictator for Life, only to be assassinated by Brutus on the Ides of March.

title: Digital recorder/player connections
description: In this video we attach and wire a digital voice recorder to Bit-zee.

title: Augustus and the Roman Empire
description: Octavian is victorious over Marc Antony and Cleopatra and becomes Augustus, first emperor of the Roman Empire.

title: Power connector for the Arduino
description: In this video we show you how to create a power connector for your arduino.

title: Great Schism or East-West Schism part 2
description: After hundreds of years of increasing division between the Latin Church led by the Pope in Rome and the Eastern. Greek church led by the Byzantine Emperor and the Patriarch of Constantinople, the Great Schism in 1054 marks the beginning of the formal division between what will be known as the Roman Catholic Church and the Eastern Orthodox Church.

title: Fall of the Roman Empire
description: The Roman Empire became less stable over the course of the Third to Fifth centuries CE. Historians point to internal divisions as well as repeated invasions from tribes such as the Huns and the Visigoths as reasons why the Empire fell. The fall of the Western Roman Empire occurred in 476 CE.

title: Introduction to the Crusades
description: The Crusades begin in reaction to Pope Urban II's call to help the Byzantine Empire reclaim land from Muslim rule (especially Jerusalem).

title: Motor controller connection to Arduino
description: In this video we show you how to determine which wire is which and how to connect them to your Arduino.

title: Camera connection to the Arduino
description: In this video we wire Bit-zee's camera's shutter and power functions to some transistors on the bread board and then we connect the transistors to the Arduino.

title: Intro to subtracting negative numbers
description: Learn why subtracting a negative number is the same as adding its opposite!

title: Impact of the crusades
description: Part 3 of the series on the Crusades. An overview of the human, territorial, commercial and political impact of the Crusades.

title: Ancient Rome
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on ancient Rome!

title: Bumper switches
description: In this video we create and wire Bit-zee's bumper switches

title: Knights Templar | World History | Khan Academy
description: Overview of the Knights Templar and their role as international banking pioneers during the Crusades.

title: Ancient and Imperial China
description: For over 3500 years, China has had a relatively continuous civilization with long-lasting dynasties. In this tutorial, we will explore some of the most significant of these early dynasties, from the Zhou to the Qin to the Han.

title: LED eyes
description: In this video we create and wire Bit-zee's tri-color LED eyes

title: Zhou, Qin and Han Dynasties
description: Sal provides a historical overview of the Zhou, Qin, and Han dynasties in China.

title: State-building: technology and cultural transfers during the Crusades
description: Read passages and answer questions about technology and cultural transfers during the Crusades.

title: Cube roots review
description: Review cube roots, and try some practice problems.

title: Microscopic structure of bone - the Haversian system
IR sensor
description: In this video we connect, bend and wire Bit-zee's IR sensor. This sensor will allow Bit-zee to receive commands from a universal remote control.

title: The Mongols
description: In the thirteenth century, the Mongols expanded rapidly out of their homeland in the Asian steppes to become the largest contiguous land empire in history.

title: Chassis modifications
description: This video shows how Bit-zee's shell was modified to allow space for the bumper switches.

title: Genghis Khan and the Mongol Empire
description: An overview of how the Mongol Empire, founded by Genghis Khan in 1206, eventually becomes the largest contiguous empire in world history before splitting formally into the Yuan Dynasty, Golden Horde, Chagatai Khanate and Ilkhanate.

title: Confucius and the Hundred Schools of Thought
description: We look at Confucianism, Daoism, and Legalism, as well as other philosophies from Warring States-era China.

title: Camera wiring update
description: This video shows you how to reduce the complexity of your Bit-zee while improving the speed of your Bit-zee digital camera.

title: Why were the Mongols so effective?
description: Owing to their adaptability, their skill in communications, and their reputation for ferocity, the Mongols swept across Eurasia over the 13th and 14th centuries, quickly assembling the largest contiguous empire in world history. These non-state actors had to quickly learn how to become a state themselves.

title: Adding & subtracting with negatives on the number line
description: Learn how to use number lines to solve negative number addition and subtraction problems.

title: The Philosophers of the Warring States
Timur
description: The Black Death ravages the Ilkhanate. Timur (Timurlane) establishes the Timurid Empire.

title: Lesson summary: Ancient and Imperial China
Ottoman, Safavid and Mughal Empires
description: Overview of the Ottoman, Safavid and Mughal Empires and their Turko-Mongol origins. Discussions of devshirme, janissaries and ghulams. Gunpowder empires.

title: Ancient and Imperial China
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on Ancient and Imperial China

title: Early Judaism
description: Judaism is the basis of the religious beliefs of roughly half the world's population (Jews, Christians and Muslims). In this tutorial, we will explore the significant biblical and historical events.

title: Square roots of perfect squares
description: Learn how to find the square root of perfect squares like 25, 36, and 81.

title: The distributive property & equivalent expressions
description: Learn how to factor and expand algebraic expressions (expressions with variables) by applying the distributive property.

title: Equations of proportional relationships
description: Learn how to write equations of proportional relationships in the form y=kx.

title: Chinese Imperial Dynasties
description: An overview of the truly Imperial Chinese Dynasties including the Qin, Han, Sui, Tang, Song, Yuan, Ming and Qing. Discussion of innovations during Tang and Song China.

title: Spanish and Portuguese Empires
description: The Spanish and Portuguese were the first Europeans to build global empires.

title: Early Judaism, part 1
description: An overview of the stories of the Torah (first 5 books of the Hebrew Bible and the Christian Old Testament).

title: Neo-Confucianism and Zhu Xi
description: A discussion of how the relative influence of Confucianism, Taoism and Buddhism has changed from the Han through the Tang and Song dynasties. Overview of Neo-Confucians, including Zhu Xi.

title: Spain, Portugal, and the creation of a global economy
description: The actions of Spain and Portugal in the sixteenth century helped to create an interconnected global economy.

title: Early Judaism, part 2
description: An overview from the first kings of a unified Judah and Israel to the beginning of the Jewish Diaspora with the destruction of the Second Temple.

title: Prosperity in Song China (960-1279)
description: Overview of innovation and causes of prosperity and stability during the Song Dynasty (both Northern and Southern Song Dynasties). First movable type block printing, government sanctioned paper money, gunpowder, etc.

title: Scientific Revolution and Enlightenment
description: Copernicus challenging the notion that Earth is the center of the Universe is usually cited as the beginning of the Scientific Revolution. A time in which brave thinkers challenged the status quo based on evidence and logic. The period is considered to culminate with Newton's _Principia_. The Enlightenment emerges out of the ideas of the Scientific Revolution as philosophers begin to challenge traditional thinking in politics and human rights.

title: Adding & subtracting integers
description: Add and subtract negative numbers using a number line. It's the 7th grade mathematics shuffle: "Slide to the left for a negative value, and slide to the right for a positive value." Be careful, though. Which way do you move if you are subtracting a negative number? The answer awaits!

title: The Scientific Revolution and the Age of Enlightenment | World History | Khan Academy
description: An overview of how the Scientific Revolution catalyzed the Age of Enlightenment with a discussion of the degree to which Enlightenment ideas have or even can be fulfilled.

title: Focus on state building: Song China
description: Read passages and answer questions about Song China.

title: Mughal rule in India
description: After over three hundred years rule over North India, the Muslim Delhi Sultanate is overthrown by the Central Asian ruler Babar (who is descended from both Timur and Genghis Khan). He starts the Mughal Dynasty ("Mughal" is the Persian word for Mongol) that brings a further Persian influence to North India. As we enter the 18th century, Mughal power declines and we see the entrance of the British into Indian affairs.

title: Mughal rule in India
description: An overview of the first 6 Mughal emperors: Babar, Humayun, Akbar, Jahangir, Shah Jahan, and Aurangzeb.

title: Topic C: Lesson 20: Solution sets to equations with two variables
Classical Japan during the Heian Period | World History | Khan Academy
description:
An overview of classical Japan. Chinese influence merges with Japanese culture. Tale of Genji by Lady Murasaki.

Watch the next video: https://www.khanacademy.org/humanitie... 

World History on Khan Academy: From the earliest civilizations to the modern world, geography, religion, trade, and politics have bound peoples and nations together — and torn them apart. Take a journey through time and space and discover the fascinating history behind the complex world we inhabit today.

About Khan Academy: Khan Academy offers practice exercises, instructional videos, and a personalized learning dashboard that empower learners to study at their own pace in and outside of the classroom. We tackle math, science, computer programming, history, art history, economics, and more. Our math missions guide learners from kindergarten to calculus using state-of-the-art, adaptive technology that identifies strengths and learning gaps. We've also partnered with institutions like NASA, The Museum of Modern Art, The California Academy of Sciences, and MIT to offer specialized content.

For free. For everyone. Forever. #YouCanLearnAnything

title: Early Christianity
description: Christianity starts as a Jewish sect on the periphery of the Roman Empire. Despite being actively persecuted, the religion grows through the Empire, eventually becoming the official state religion.

title: Early Christianity
description: An overview of the life and teachings of Jesus Christ and the birth of Christianity.

title: Shoguns, samurai and the Japanese Middle Ages
description: An overview of the Japanese Medieval period in which Shoguns ruled under the bakufu (shogunate) feudal system. Discussion of daimyo during the Kamakura and Muromachi/Ashikaga periods. Samurai and bushido.

title: Sikhism
description: Guru Nanak begins a movement focused on devotional love of God. It develops in a context of emerging Mughal rule. Forged by bouts of persecution by the Mughal Emperors, it develops a martial culture with the goal of fighting oppression.

title: Maya, Aztec, and Inca
description: An overview of the Maya, Aztec, and Inca civilizations.

title: Sikhism introduction
description: An overview of the founding of the Sikh religion started by Guru Nanak. Discussion of persecution by the Mughals and militarization by Gurus Har Gobind, Teg Bahadur and Gobind Singh. Overview of Khalsa.

title: Adding & subtracting negative fractions
description: Learn how to add and subtract fractions, even when they're negative.

title: The spread of Christianity
description: After Jesus, the two most significant figures in Christianity are the apostles Peter and Paul/Saul. Paul, in particular, takes a leading role in spreading the teachings of Jesus to Gentiles (non Jews) in the Roman Empire.

title: Aztec Empire
description: An overview of how Tenochtitlan creates the tributary Aztec Empire in the 15th Century (from the Triple Alliance). They rule until being conquered by Hernando Cortez.

title: Continuity-Sikhism connections to Hinduism and Islam
description: Exploring Sikhism's cultural and thematic connections to Hinduism and Islam.

title: The heart is a double pump
Compound events and sample spaces
description: Learn about sample spaces and probability for compound events.  Learn the counting principle.

title: The Protestant Reformation
description: In 1517 a German theologian and monk, Martin Luther, challenged the authority of the Pope and sparked the Protestant Reformation. His ideas spread quickly, thanks in part to the printing press. By challenging the power of the Church, and asserting the authority of individual conscience (it was increasingly possible for people to read the bible in the language that they spoke), the Reformation laid the foundation for the value that modern culture places on the individual.

title: Inca Empire overview
description: An overview of the Inca Empire, or Tawantinsuyu, founded by Pachacuti from the Kingdom of Cusco. The Mit'a system and eventual conquest by Pizarro.

title: An introduction to the Protestant Reformation
Focus on state building: Maya, Aztec, and Inca civilizations
description: Read passages and answer questions about the Maya, Aztec, and Inca civilizations.

title: Addition & subtraction word problems with negatives
description: See how adding and subtracting negative numbers can be used in different situations.

title: The Russian Empire
description: From its medieval, Nordic-Slav roots as the 'land of Rus', Russia will eventually break free of Mongol control and emerge as a significant empire in Eastern Europe and Northern Asia.

title: Environment and trade
description: Environments had profound impacts on the ways people could conduct trade.

title: How did Russia begin?
description: Using the Russian Primary Chronicle to explore the early Nordic and Slavic beginnings of the "Land of Rus'" or the "Kievan State", including the start of the Rurukid Dynasty by Rurik.

title: Addition within 100
description: Learn to add two-digit numbers like 37 and 49.

title: Early medieval trade
description: Is a ring from a ninth-century Viking grave a surprising find, or a reflection of the larger trade patterns in early medieval Europe and the Middle East? Vikings traded and raided throughout Europe and as far as the Abbasid Caliphate in the Middle East. Political circumstances and environmental factors shaped these patterns of trade.

title: Early Judaism and Early Christianity
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on Judaism and early Christianity!

title: American Revolution
description: The United States is the first major nation to break the chains of colonialism and rule by a king, based on ideas of the Enlightenment. It sets the stage for the French Revolution and multiple revolution in the early 19th century throughout the Americas. It can be viewed in the context of a broader struggle between England and France.

title: Early Americas
description: Thousands of years before the Europeans began to colonize the Americas, many, complex civilizations had risen on these two continents.

title: Background and introduction to the United States Declaration of Independence
description: In this video, Aspen Institute President and CEO Walter Isaacson talks to Sal about the background to the Declaration of Independence.

title: Environment and Trade: Viking Age
description: Between the eighth and eleventh centuries, Vikings not only raided, but traded far and wide. Environmental and political contexts shaped this trade.

title: Pre-contact Americas
description: Sal provides an overview of the population and civilizations in the Americas over the past sixteen thousand years.

title: French Revolution
description:
"Let them eat cake!"  "No, how about we cut your head off instead!"  

The French Revolution was ugly, bloody and idealistic.  This tutorial covers the beginning of the end of the Bourbon rule (actually doesn't really go away for 60 years) and birth of France as a Republic (which will really take about 80 years).

title: Focus on environment: trade
description: Read passages and answer questions about the the relationship between environment, politics, and trade.

title: Absolute value
description: Find the distance between any two numbers using absolute value.

title: French Revolution (part 1)
description: Part 1 of the French Revolution. From the Convocation of the Estates General to the storming of the Bastille. For extra coverage of the French Revolution outside the scope of the AP course, click here.

title: Human migration
description: Various factors affect whether people choose to leave their homes and make new lives. We will explore the history and impacts of migration.

title: Japanese Imperialism
description: An overview of Japanese Imperialism in the 19th and 20th centuries. Discussion of imperial powers in East Asia, the Opium Wars and the Meiji Restoration.

title: Adding & subtracting negative numbers: variables
description: Feeling positive about all of this negative number stuff? Challenge yourself to solve some more advanced problems, including expressions with variables.

title: Empires in India
description: As we transition from the end of the Vedic Period, we enter into a time of the first significant empire formation in India. Both the Maurya and Gupta empires will have lasting impact not only on India, but the world.

title: Latin American independence
description: From the late 1700s through the mid 1800s, most of North and South America achieves independence from European colonial powers. Possible catalyst include the ideas of the Enlightenment from the early 1700s, and the turmoil in Europe at the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th centuries (French Revolution, Napoleonic Wars, etc.). You also have the emergence of revolutionary figures like Simon Bolivar.

title: Causes and effects of human migration
description: Causes and effects of human migration in Africa and the Pacific.

title: Focus on causation: Human migration
description: Let's explore more perspectives on why populations moved.

title: Imperialism
description: As nations begin to industrialize, their desire for raw materials and markets in which to sell their products grows. In the 19th century, these factors motivated imperialist tendencies, especially among Western European powers.

title: Properties of addition & subtraction
description: Apply the properties of addition and subtraction to negative numbers.

title: Mayan civilization
description: An overview of the Mayan civilization as well as the great city of Teotihuacan.

title: Development of new trading cities
description: As trade routes expanded, so did major trading cities such as Hangzhou, Malacca, and Timbuktu

title: Industrialization and imperialism
description: Thinking about how the Industrial Revolution(s) and capitalism helped catalyze far-flung imperialism during the 1800s.

title: Chavin, Nazca, Moche, Huari and Tiwanaku civilizations
description: Learn about several of the pre-Columbian civilizations that emerged around the Andes in and near modern-day Peru.

title: Development of new trading cities
description: Trading cities played an important role in the spread of goods on the Silk Road and Indian Ocean trade routes.

title: Opium Wars
description: The British wage two wars on China to have better access to Chinese markets, especially to sell opium grown in British India.

title: Focus on economy: development of new trading cities
description: Read passages and answer questions about trade and economy in trading cities.

title: Early Americas
description: Practice your skills with a quiz on early Americas!

title: Cultural interactions along trade routes
description: We'll look at how the Srivijaya Empire, an empire on the Malay Peninsula lasting from the seventh to the twelfth century, was shaped by its interactions with its chief trading partners.

title: The Srivijaya Empire: trade and culture in the Indian Ocean
description: The Srivijaya Empire controlled modern-day Indonesia and much of the Malay Archipelago from the seventh to twelfth centuries. The empire traded extensively with India and China, incorporating Buddhist and Chinese political practices into their traditions.

title: The rise of empires in India
description: In the late 4th century, the Maurya Empire under Chandragupta conquers most of North India. His son Bindusara continues the conquest into the south. Bindusara's son Ashoka (Asoka) takes the empire to its furthest extent, but then turns to a life of Buddhism and nonviolence. He is considered one of the prime catalysts for the spread of Buddhism.

title: Empires before World War I
description: Austria-Hungary. Ottoman empire. British, German, French and Russian empires.  For extra coverage of World War 1 outside the scope of the AP course, click here.

title: Focus on cultural interactions: Srivijaya Empire
description: Read passages and answer questions about the way the Srivijaya Empire interacted with other cultures.

title: Gupta Dynasty
description: India experienced a golden age during the Gupta Dynasty; find out why and how!

title: The Great War begins
description: World War I began after Serbian nationalist Gavrilo Princip assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of the Austro-Hungarian Empire on June 28, 1914. Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia, whose ally Russia then mobilized for war. An alliance between Germany and Austria then prompted Germany to preemptively declare war on Russia, Serbia, and Russia's ally France. Germany then attacked France through Belgium, activating an alliance between the United Kingdom and Belgium, and the United Kingdom declared war on Germany and Austria-Hungary.

title: Development of financial institutions
description: Financial institutions, specifically banks, developed as a result of cross-cultural interactions and the need to pay for trade and war.

title: Financial institutions
description: Banking originated in medieval Italy but was based on mathematical knowledge acquired from wide-reaching trade interactions.

title: Sykes-Picot Agreement and the Balfour Declaration
Focus on spread of knowledge: financial institutions
description: Read a passage and answer questions about cross-cultural transfers of knowledge in financial institutions.

title: Early Hinduism
description: Often considered the world's oldest living religion, Hinduism is still practiced by over 1 billion people despite having roots in the Vedic Period and the Indus Valley Civilization. It is also one of the most diverse and open religions.

title: Disease and demography
description: How did the plague spread? We'll cover the history of the plague in Europe.

title: Hinduism: core ideas of Brahman, Atman, Samsara and Moksha.
description: Hinduism is one of the oldest and largest religions in the world. It is also one of the most diverse in terms of practice. This video gives an overview of the central spiritual ideas of Brahman, Atman, Samsara and Moksha.

title: Bubonic Plague
description: The plague, named the Black Death by later historians, had a devastating effect on the European population in the fourteenth century.

title: Multiply & divide negative numbers
description: You already know how to multiply and divide whole numbers, decimals, and fractions. See what happens when we throw negative numbers into the mix. It's really not so different!

title: World War II
description: World War II was the bloodiest conflict in human history.    Starting with the Second Sino-Japanese War (1937) and the Nazi invasion of Poland (1939) through the eventual Axis power surrenders, this tutorial walks through the major events, year by year, in both the European and Pacific Arenas.

title: The history of Hinduism
description: During the Maurya and Gupta empires, the Indian culture and way of life were deeply influenced by Hinduism.

title: Focus on context: disease and demography
description: Read passages and check your understanding of the Black Death.

title: Equation with variables on both sides: fractions
description: Sal solves the equation (3/4)x + 2 = (3/8)x - 4.

title: 1 and -1 to different powers
description: Use odd and even rules to determine the sign of an exponential expression.

title: Working with powers of 10
description: This tutorial leads in to scientific notation. It features multiplication and division problems involving powers of 10.

title: Constructing triangles
description: Let's practice making triangles and start thinking about when it's possible or impossible to make a triangle.

title: Worked example: Evaluating functions from equation
description: Learn how to evaluate f(x)=49-x² at x=5.

title: ADH secretion
description: Learn the key triggers for ADH secretion.  Rishi is a pediatric infectious disease physician and works at Khan Academy.

title: Recognize functions from graphs
description: Determine whether a given graph represents a function.

title: Determining translations
description: Learn how to find the necessary translation to map a given source shape onto a given image shape.

title: Topic E: First-person video games—projection matrices
Initial rise of Hitler and the Nazis
description: The beginnings of Nazism. For extra coverage of World War 2 outside the scope of the AP course, click here.

title: Social institutions in the Islamic world
description: An overview of Medieval Muslim societies.

title: Hindu gods overview
description: An overview of the Hindu pantheon including: Shiva, Vishnu, Brahma, Ganesh, Parvati, Durga, Lakshmi, Karthikeya, Rama and Krishna.

title: Hitler and the Nazis come to power
Medieval Muslim societies
description: Learn about the social hierarchies in medieval societies under Muslim rule.

title: Hindu scripture overview
description: An overview of the important religious texts in Hinduism including the Vedas, Ramayana, Mahabharata and Bhagavad Gita.

title: Focus on social structures: gender in medieval Muslim societies
description: Read passages and answer questions about the causes of gender hierarchies in medieval Muslim societies.

title: Varnas and the Caste System
description: A discussion of how varnas as described in the Rigveda and Bhagavad Gita relate to the notion of "caste" in modern India.

title: Allende and Pinochet in Chile
description: Outline of the 1973 Allende Coup in Chile and Pinochet's Junta (this video under CC-BY-SA)

title: Buddhism: context and comparison
description: Why did Buddhism emerge when and where it did? Are there other historical parallels to the emergence of Buddhism?
